Description: The first church at Trinity was erected in 1729, and the current church is the 3rd on the site. First year-round settlers from Placencia after they were forced out in the 17th century. Located on a slight rise in the landscape on the east coast of the landform, overlooking the ocean.

Site: Old RC Cemetery, Bay de Verde
Description: The oldest gravestone on the site dates to 1832 but the site was likely used earlier. The first RC church in the town was built in the corner of this plot in 1810, suggesting that the area was used previously.
Earliest recorded burial is for one Benjamin Raish, 1770. Records were kept with the Anglican Church, suggesting that there was an organized burial ground here prior to the modern church.

Old Graveyard Municiple Heritage Site was donated to the town by Thomas Nash, the first settler/planter in the area, who was of Roman Catholic faith, in the late 1700s or early 1800s. Nash previously lived on the 'Calvert Shore'. Oldest surviving headstones are from the 1850s.
The first minister visited in the 1790s and a church surveyed for this year and erected shortly after. The current UC church stands on that same site.

The earliest graves dates to 1766, elevated in the settlement to the north of the site. While services were sometimes held in a nearby home, there was no established church in the area until the 1800s. The site is likely non-denominational or Anglican.
Located near the Wareham's Lane Cemetery, the Mercer Family Plot was placed on family land with a view of the ocean and protected from wind by trees and a rock face.
Established in the 1795 with several contemporanious gravestones still present, the oldest portion of this cemetery faced the sea.

Site: Old St. Nicholas Anglican Cemetery, Torbay
Description: While the earliest recorded burial at this site was in 1674, the burial ground wasn't considered consecrated until 1827. It was used until 1967.
The church was established at this site in 1765, and the site has seen continuous use to present day. Several 18th-century gravestones still present on the sloped side facing the ocean.
While there was no church present at this site, the land was donated to the town in 1799 by the Thistle Family.
Located on the site of the current museum, all graves were moved when the chapel was torn down, and the new church was built down the road.

Site: Immaculate Conception RC Cemetery, Brigus South
Description: There appears to never have been a church associated with this site, records suggest that it has been used for burials since the 17th-century. Oldest surviving stone dates from 1750.

According to Pocius, the Conception Bay area settlers tended to bury their dead all over before the establishment of churchyards in the late 1700s. There were several organized and notable small burial grounds in Port de Grave.

Site: Second Church of St. John's Episcopal, Hampton VA
Description: There were burials associated with this settlement. The site was located north of the contemporanious settlement, and was preceeded by the 'First Church' whose location is currently unknown.

Site: First St. Paul's Church, Baltimore MD
Description: Located to the north original settlement, at the headwaters of Colgate Creek, and near the intersections of Sollers Point Rd and an unknown road which no longer exists. The exact location of the original church and burial ground remain unknown.

While there were once 18th century gravestones at the site they are all lost now. but they have been removed long ago. It's likely that the graveyard has been here since the first anglican chapel was built on this site (there have been several), and prior to that the burials were under the fish flakes and stages, as mentioned in historic accounts.

Site: Third Church, St.John's Episcopal, Hampton VA
Description: An Anglican church, located to the west of the main part of the settlement at the time, but indicates that there was a growth towards the river. The church website indicates that there are 17th and 18th century headstones in the churchyard of this site.
Located in the centre of the fort, the settlers constructed a church and created a traditional English churchyard concept, complete with important burials at the Alter.

Site: Old Settler's Cemetery (Thrashers), South Portland ME
Description: Not associated with a church, fortifications, or anything. Currently located on a college campus.
This site is elevated in the settlement, and likely had no meeting house associated with the space.

Associated with an Anglican Chapel built in 1636, this site was actually a graveyard, and was later disbanded and a new burial ground was established to the north west in the mid-later 17th century, associated with the Puritan congrigation that formed when the Massachusetts Bay Company took over the Maine territory in 1652. This site was 'lost to time' and rediscovered in the 20th century.
Located in the south of the settlement. Not associated with a meeting house (originally on Middle Lane / Church Street to the north) and on the ocean, but not in view of the ocean.

On a hill overlooking the harbour, not directly associated with the church location. Oldest stone was from the 1700s, but the settlement has been there since the 1600s, and it is likely that the burial ground is older as well.
The earliest headstones date to the early-mid 1700s, likely established before that. No church on property and the grounds are on a hill in the centre of town, overlooking the ocean.

Site: Fort St. George, Popham Colony, ME
Description: The colony failed in 1608. John Hunt created a map of the settlement that marks out everything they were building and had built. 'The Chapell' is marked out within the settlement with a defined church yard around it for the burial ground. A few people died at the settlement and this area was likely intended for them.
The second burial ground in the area, preceeded by the Ancient Norwich Burying Ground to the west. Raised, and in the centre of the town.

Site: Ancient Norwich Burying Ground, Norwich CT
Description: The first burying ground in the town, on land owned by Thomas Post. The site is also called the Post and Gager Cemetery. None of the gravestones remainat the site, but there is a monument commemorating the land to the first founders.
Elevated within the settlement, the second burial ground in Salem

The Oldest burial ground in Salem MA. The land was set aside for the graveyard, and later the rights to graze cattle there were granted. Not associated with the meeting house, which had been constructed 4 years prior and was on the corner of Washington and Essex street to the NW of the burial grounds.

Site: Meeting House Hill Burying Ground, Old Lyme CT
Description: Located on a hill overlooking the town, it was associated with the first meeting house in Old Lyme.

Site: Duck River Burying Ground, Old Lyme CT
Description: Established after the town began spreading, this site was preceeded by the Meeting House Hill burying ground.

Site: Old Cove Burying Ground, East Haddam CT
Description: The settlement was established in the 1670's, but the space the burying ground wasn't set aside until 1690s (91/92). It was elevated in the settlement and not associated with a church or meeting house.

Site: Old Witless Bay Cemetery, Witless Bay
Description: Witless Bay cemetery, according to the Canadian historic places registry, states that gravestones from the early 1800's survive, and a number of unmarked stones likely from the early 1700's are present, when occupation began in ernest in the area.  The English Pilot 4th Book from 1689 states that planters lived in 'Witlesse Bay'.

Site: Guilford Green Burial Ground, Guilford CT
Description: The burial ground was established in the centre of the most populated area in Guilford just after the town's founding in 1639. In 1800 it was said that 'this square, like that in New Haven, is deformed by a burying ground, and to add to the deformity is unenclosed.' - Timothy Dwight The first meeting house was build in 1643 in the NE quadrant of the green, and thus was not immediately associated with the burial ground.

Site: Ye Antientist Burial Ground, New London CT
Description: The site was established on a hill overlooking the harbour, with the meetinghouse adjoining at one time. This structure is no longer present, and the burial ground is in a partially overgrown state, with some gravestones broken or vandalized.

Site: Little Compton Commons, Little Compton RI
Description: Land was set assite for the burial ground and meeting house together, which was 'completely at odds with Rhode Island settlements', in the centre of town.

Site: First Burying Grounds, St. Mary's City, MD
Description: Associated with the historic church at St. Mary's City, which no longer stands, the burials were located within the fortifications of the town, slightly elevated, and consisted of a traditional church and churchyard.
This site was established to the west of the original settlement of Wallingford, not associated with a meeting house or church.

Established prior to the first meeting house, this burial ground was a municiple, non-denominational establishment in the settlement. The meeting house was built on the burial ground later on, following the trend of the Church establishing rule of the municiple lots in New England later in the colonial period.
Yorktown VA, established in 1691, and the burial ground likely dates to around this date. The entire area was fortified with the church in the middle of town by the coast. A traditional churchyard.
The oldest surviving burial ground in Portsmouth, NH. The area had been settled by Europeans since the 1630's, but no evidence exists suggesting that they had another burial ground.

This site was established later than other municiple burial grounds, as churchyard burials were not as popular in Virgina and they prefered to bury their dead in family plots on their own land. The Burial Ground was established in 1678, 60 feet in all directions around the church. The land was donated by Mr. John Page, near the centre of the original survey map for the city.

Site: Bell Rock / Sandy Bank Cemetery, Malden MA
Description: The burial ground was established in the 1640's, prior to the town separating from itss previous county.

Site: New Haven Green, New Haven CT
Description: This site was established in 1638 as a part of the 9 cell plan for New Haven, burials stopped in the 19th-century. Headstones have been moved to a nearby church, and the site is now a park. The meeting house not built til 1668.
This site was established far from the first church in the settlement. It was built within the fortifications, to the north end of the original settlement.

Site: Old North Burying Ground , Ipswich MA
Description: To the west of the original settlement, the burial ground is located on the base of and up a slope, and was founded in 1634.

Potentially established in the 1650's - 1670's, this burial ground is within close reach of the first parish church / meetinghouse of Newbury. It is east of the original settlement area, and is not elevated because of the river flood plane. Not a fortified settlement, though according to the church website the first settlers had to bar the doors of the meeting house during services to save from getting attacked by the indiginous peoples.

Site: Burying Ground of the First Settlers , Newbury MA
Description: Founded in 1635, the graveyard was restored in 1929. There was no church or meeting house associated with this burial ground.

The 3rd oldest burial ground in Boston, the site got its name from a later granary across the street (1700's). Not near a church until 1809 when the park street church was constructed. The site is slightly elevated

Site: Copp's Hill Burial Ground, Boston MA
Description: This site was originally a windmill and farmland, was named for family that owned land (William Copp, on a 1645 map).  It is located on a hill to the north of the original settlement area and the oldest part of the site overlooks the ocean.

Site: King's Chapel Burying Ground , Boston MA
Description: Boston's first burial ground, and the only one for 30ish years, King's Chapel Burying Ground was established in 1630. The Chapel (Anglican) was build on top of part of the burial ground in 1688 and was not originally associated with the Puritan site. Build on a slight slope on the edge of old downtown, centre of living area, and was barely marked on period maps.

Site: Men of Kent Cemetery, Scituate MA
Description: In the Town of Scituate, established in the 1620s and encorperated in 1636, with the burial ground being established in 1624 on a high point, 3/4 miles from the water. The first meeting house was build on/beside the site later on.

Site: First Parish Burial Ground, Gloucester MA
Description: Used to be in the center of Gloucester (established 1623), the cemetery was established closer to 1644 and was the only one in the town for 80 years.

First burial ground at Plymouth, associated with the first landing of settlers at Plymouth rock. Very near to the later established Burial Hill, it was able to be fortified in case of attack to the early settlement.

Established 1622, on the hill overlooking what is now Leyden St, Plymouth, where the settlement was established. The heart of the settlement was at 'Town Square' (modern name) at the southeast edge of burial hill. Originally called 'Fort Hill', Burial hill had a fort/meeting house and a watchtower to protect the settlement as errected in 1622 near the southeast corner of the burying ground. Church services were held in the building's ground floor.

Established at the site of the first Meeting house of Marblehead, to the north of the occupation area on the shore on a hill overlooking settlement to the south and with views of the ocean.  Marblehead was established in 1631 as an extention of Salem on the 'Salem' side, though the occupation around the harbour area grew quickly for fishing and farming as well. Old Burial Hill is associated with the harbour occupation.

Site: The Common Burial Ground, Newport RI
Description: Located to the north of the original settlement, SW slope towards the water. Used potentially up until modern day, very ornate sculpture in later periods of use in a garden style cemetery.

Burial ground likelystablished approximately 1610 -/+.  Unknown if it is within fortifications or not, excavations have not been undertaken to determine this as of yet. Burial ground location currently unknown, though detailed records of deaths at the plantation indicate that one would have to be nearby.
Established in the mid-18th century, this burial ground is associated with later growth in Ferryland as an occupational area, post Calvert era.

Several field stones associated with the site suggest it might be early 1700's or late 1600's. Large area, within proximity with the original occupational area around the Pool Plantation, though more likely associated with the 1700's push onto the main shores.  Located on east southeast facing slope, wth original C17th occupational area to the east in the Pool.
There were no year-round settlers in Cape Broyle until the later 18th century, but it is likely that the burial ground predates this. The earliest surviving gravestones date to the mid 19th-century.
